head.title: Yet Another Draw, and Time Grows Short for Kasparov

hedline.hl1: Yet Another Draw, and Time Grows Short for Kasparov

abstract.p: Robert Byrne chess column on Game 11 between Garry Kasparov and Vladimir Kramnik in London; diagram (S)

block.p: Time is running out for Garry Kasparov, but he conducted Game 11 against Vladimir Kramnik, the challenger for the world championship, as though he were taking a rest stop.

Time is running out for Garry Kasparov, but he conducted Game 11 against Vladimir Kramnik, the challenger for the world championship, as though he were taking a rest stop.

The draw the players agreed upon after 41 moves made the score Kramnik 6 1/2, Kasparov 4 1/4, but the champion seemed to be without ambition. All Kramnik, 25, needs is two victories or four draws to sew it up.
It is understandable that Kasparov would like to recuperate from his grievous loss in Game 10, but that is a luxury he cannot afford at this stage.

The defense to the Ruy Lopez featuring 6 . . . Bc5 is not new, but it lacks a name because it was believed for many years to be an error. The refutation was supposed to be 7 Ne5 Ne5 8 d4 Bd4 9 Qd4, but it has now been appreciated that after 9 . . . d6 10 c3 O-O 11 f3 c5 12 Qd1 h6 13 a4 Bb7 14 ab ab 15 Ra8 Ba8 16 Na3 Bc6 17 Bf4 Qe7, Black's game is quite sound.
With 9 . . . Na5, Kramnik offers what has come to be considered a respectable positional gambit. Kasparov knows its ins and outs and so does Kramnik.
Kasparov had introduced 14 Bg5 against Alexei Shirov in Linares 1998, but after 14 . . . Be7 15 Nb5 de 16 de Be4, Shirov had no trouble making a draw.
After 16 . . . b4, Kasparov made the only original move of the game, 17 Bf6, but it led to a sterile endgame in which the denouement was a technical exercise. Was he hoping for something more?
After 19 Bd6 20 Nf8 Kf8, material was even, a rook and two pawns opposed to two bishops. After that, the players were running on empty.

On 42 gf, there could follow 42 . . . Be4 43 Kf4 Bd6 44 Kg5 Ba3 45 f7 Ke5, and Kramnik will exchange a bishop for the last pawn and enter into the routinely drawn rook versus bishop endgame. On 42 g6, there could follow 42 . . . Be4 43 Kf6 Bd4 44 Kf7 Be5 45 g7 Bg7 with the same result.
Game 12 begins tomorrow at 3 p.m. London time (10 a.m. Eastern Daylight Time).
